title: Asking for ideas on how to debug an issue better
body:
## â”Question

Hi, after a few changes in my code, I'm running `test.py` and in one of the batches (for COCO) I'm getting this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7031523/88438901-9fd44800-ce01-11ea-9268-3791a8542b73.png)

As it is possible to see, some bunding boxes are getting outside the image, even though the code seems to correct those cases (with clip_coords).

In order to find what changes in my code produced this error, I thought I should start by highlighting in `test.py` where the "bad" bounding boxes occur, by adding the following code:
```python
for i in range(box.shape[0]):
    if box[i, 1].item() > shapes[si][0][0] or box[i, 0].item() > shapes[si][0][1] or \
     box[i, 1].item() < 0 or  box[i, 0].item() < 0:
        print('Bad bounding box at xy1 coordinate')
```
right before where the bounding boxes are saved in the json (ie, adding the previous code in line 130):
https://github.com/ultralytics/yolov3/blob/e80cc2b80e3fd46395e8ec75f843960100927ff2/test.py#L131

I would expect this place to be a good one to start debugging, but this is never printed. Which made me think that maybe I've misunderstood how `shapes` work here...

Could you please help me in understanding what I'm doing wrong? It seemed to me that `shapes[si][0]` contains the (height, width) of the original image, thus I was comparing every bounding box in `box` against it, while checking for negative coordinates.
